phrase.item: A smart, bald [boy].
Once upon a time there was a man.
He had two wives.
One was pampered, one was despised.
By the pampered [wife] he had two sons, by the despised [wife] one.
One day the man died.
The wives went apart.
The two brothers were envious of the one who was called bald [their half-brother].
The bald one did everything before them.
At night they burned the bald one's wheat stook.
He woke up in the morning and saw there was nothing [left].
He loaded up the ash and left.
He met a man, and the man asked him, "Hey bald one, where are you going?"
He said, "I am taking this gold to the king."
The man said, "My bald friend, I have never seen gold, can you please show me?"
The bald one said, "No, some people have bad eyes, the gold might turn to dirt or ash.
I will fulfill the King's order."
The man said, "Please, my bald friend, show me just once.
I don't think I have that bad eye."
Then he opened [the bag], and there was only ash.
Then he [the bald one] started crying and said,"What I am going to tell the king now?"
The man started begging him.
He said, "In exchange I will give you the loads of two or three camels, just don't tell him anything about me."
The bald one was saying no, no, but then he agreed.
He took the load of the two or three camels and came home.
His brothers saw him and asked, "Bald one, where did you get all these things?"
He said, "Oh dear brothers, in a city they are giving this many goods in exchange for ash.
I woke up in the morning and saw that my wheat stook was burned, so I took the ash and sold it."
They also burned their stook, loaded the ash on two donkeys and left. On the way they asked whoever they met, "Who wants to take our ash and give us goods?"
The people said, "Are you crazy? We throw our ash outside, and you are selling it?"
The brothers could do nothing and they returned.
They decided that all these things were being taught to the bald one by his mother.
[They decided that] when the Bald would go somewhere, they would kill his mother.
The next day, the bald one went to work.
When he returned, he saw that his mother was killed.
Then he loaded the corpse onto a donkey.
He put a branch on her jaw,
and left.
He went to a place and saw that people were having tea on their land.
The bald one directed the donkey towards the grain.
Then he went outside for a walk.
A man called loudly, [telling him] to take the donkey away from the grain.
He stayed far away quietly.
The man ??? ???
The corpse fell down.
The bald one came in crying, "You killed my mother.
The king requested her."
The man said, "How many times did I tell you to take your donkey away from the grain?"
The bald one said, "Now what should I do and what should I tell the king?"
The man said, "Oh bald one, I have a beautiful daughter, take her to the king instead."
The bald one said, "No, that is not enough."
[The man] said, "I will give you several bags of wheat as well."
The bald one agreed.
In the evening he loaded his donkey and came [home] with the girl.
Again his brothers asked him, "Where did you get these things?"
The bald one replied, "In the city they are exchanging corpses for living people.
I sold my mother's body and bought a wife and wheat."
The brothers also killed their mother and started calling,
"Who will give [us] a living person for the corpse?"
The people said, "Hey, shame on you, we bury our corpses and you are exchanging yours for a living [person]?"
The brothers returned upset.
Then they said, "We should kill the bald one himself,
he made us lose our bread and our mother."
Then they put the bald one in a bag in order to throw him in the river.
They walked for a long time and got very thirsty.
In that moment, the bald one heard the sound of a reedpipe.
And he started calling, "I won't become a king, I won't become a king."
That moment the shepherd came closer to him and stopped playing the reedpipe.
He came and opened the bag.
Then he asked him, "Who are you and why don't you want to be a king?"
Bald said, "I am forced to become a king.
I don't have enough power for that.
Now they put me inside a bag and taking me there.
Why don't you become a king instead of me and I will be a shepherd?"
The man agreed; he came out of the bag and the man got in.
The bald one warned him not to make a sound, otherwise they won't take him.
And he led the flock away.
The brothers came and lifted the bag and threw it in the river.
And they returned home saying that they had gotten rid of the bald one.
In the evening the bald one came home playing a reedpipe with the flock ahead of him.
The brothers were surprised and asked him, "Where are all these from?"
"You threw me in at the edge [of the river].
In the middle [of the river] there are sheep worth seeing [i.e., very good sheep]."
The brothers said, "We made a ???
The bald one said, "Sounds good."
In the morning they left.
He drove the flock and called his brothers saying, "Let's go, you should also get [a flock] for yourself".
They left and they saw there the reflection of the flock in the river.
The bald one asked his brothers, "Do you see the flock over there?"
They said, "Yes!"
Then one brother jumped in the [river] and his hands were coming out of the water as he drowned.
The bald one said, "Your brother is calling you."
The other one also jumped in the water
and drowned.
The bald one with his cleverness had gotten rid of his enemies.
He had a flock, wealth, and a family and lived his life happily.
